title: Buck Perley, Bitcoin, The Great Ride, Freedom and Truth, Complexity is Subsidy
description:
Buck Perley’s background:  Software Engineer and Open Source Contributor
Economics and Chinese language

Series of essays on bitcoin by Buck Perley: (Part 1 of 3). https://medium.com/bcoin-io/what-gives-bitcoin-value-pt-1-7be2ff880d9c

Buck’s article on governance and Bitcoin
https://medium.com/@BuckPerley/crypto-governance-f1318affbbe0

The Road to Serfdom by Friedrich Hayek
Favorite podcast:  EconTalk

Man desires not only to be loved but to be lovely.
Complexity is a subsidy
Big companies lobby to be regulated because the regulations will inhibit newcomers  or existing smaller companies because the costs of compliance are disproportionate.
Federalist 10 and the power of faction
The U. S. Constitution protects us from our worst impulses
The tyranny of the experts
Complexity is subsidy
Notes from Buck on the Constitution:  In terms of resources to read more about a lot of this stuff, the primary sources are honestly a really great place to start. I learned so much just from reading the Federalist Papers by Madison, Hamilton, and Jay and you can't go wrong with reading the Constitution and Declaration of Independence.

Notes from Buck on Bitcoin:  For Bitcoin, the white paper includes a lot and isn't too technical either (https://nakamotoinstitute.org/bitcoin/ - from the Nakamoto Institute which has a lot of great primary resources on the progenitors of Bitcoin as well as Austrian economics influences). Another one I mentioned was Hayek's Free Market Money: https://fee.org/articles/hayeks-free-market-money/

Motorcycling across China - 38,000 kilometers, every province
Raising money for school lunches for village children in China
Resources for exploring the Great Ride:
Video of The Great Ride Across China:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b0kuUkNRFQ8 
Website:  http://thegreatrideofchina.com
Book:  The Great Ride of China by Buck Perley
https://www.amazon.com/Great-Ride-China-two-wheeled-adventure-ebook/dp/B072YSNJYZ
Also, photobook of the journey by Amy Perley
https://www.amazon.com/Great-Ride-China-Exploring-Motorcycle/dp/0999074628

https://youtu.be/OJSagODtV3o

Books mentioned during the conversation:

A Walk Across America by Peter Jenkins:  https://www.amazon.com/Walk-Across-America-Peter-Jenkins/dp/160671323X/ref=pd_lpo_sbs_14_t_1?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=1N7464X9SQ19VC44JD7K

Travels with Charley by John Steinbeck
On the Road by Mark Twain

The Road to Serfdom by Friedrich Hayek
Favorite podcast:  EconTalk

Selected quotes from Buck’s article on Bitcoin:

“Incredible research is taking place to explore more efficient rule enforcement mechanisms, such as Proof of Stake vs. Bitcoin’s Proof of Work, but even these spend more time discussing how to more efficiently punish bad actors than the mechanisms that decide what constitutes a “bad actor” in the first place. This is like debating the most efficient way to put criminals in jail before discussing how to define what makes someone a criminal in the first place.”

“The nature of humanity - put not your trust in Princes.”

“To say that governance isn’t necessary at all, or that even wanting governance represents a kind of power play, seems to me to naively misunderstand the nature of humanity. Even in a system governed by code, this viewpoint assumes there exist objective, final truths. The problem though is that we all live in our own subjective worlds with subjective values all of varying degrees of validity. Distribution of information isn’t perfect, and distrust among groups is a natural byproduct. Further, to believe this is to ignore that, unlike gold which is physical and immutable, a cryptocurrency is comprised of code that can be improved and innovated on in an infinite number of ways, and from this underestimates the power and scope of that innovation while ignoring its capacity, in a subjective world, to create controversy.
This is something the U.S. founders were keenly aware of in the framing of a constitution- the capacity for humanity to evolve in unpredictable ways. So they created, however imperfectly practiced, a system based on universal and timeless values. In the words of Calvin Coolidge:
About the Declaration there is a finality that is exceedingly restful… If all men are created equal, that is final. If governments derive their just powers from the consent of the governed, that is final. No advance, no progress can be made beyond these propositions. If anyone wishes to deny their truth or their soundness, the only direction in which he can proceed historically is not forward, but backward toward the time when there was no equality, no rights of the individual, no rule of the people.”
